**Ori and the Will of the Wisps ‚Äì A Near-Perfect Masterpiece (10/10)**

I just finished my second playthrough of *Ori and the Will of the Wisps* and I‚Äôm still in awe. Everything about this game feels like it was crafted with pure love.

From the very first moment, the visuals absolutely floor you. The hand-painted art style is breathtaking ‚Äî every layer of parallax, every glowing particle, every blade of grass swaying in the wind looks like a living painting. When you sprint across the glowing sands of the Wellspring or glide through the midnight-blue depths of Luma Pools with the water effects rippling around Ori, it‚Äôs genuinely jaw-dropping. This is one of the most beautiful games ever made, period.

The soundtrack? Moon Studios somehow topped the already legendary *Blind Forest* score. Gareth Coker‚Äôs music swells and crashes with your emotions ‚Äî gentle piano in quiet moments, thunderous orchestral bursts during escapes, heartbreaking strings when the story hits you right in the chest. I still get chills every single time ‚ÄúA Stirring from the Ruins‚Äù kicks in.

Gameplay is buttery smooth and endlessly satisfying. The movement upgrades feel amazing ‚Äî triple jump, bash, dash, burrow, glide, grapple‚Ä¶ everything flows together so naturally that by the end you‚Äôre chaining abilities like a speedrunner even if you‚Äôre just playing casually. Combat is weighty and fun (the new spirit weapons feel great), and the chase sequences are some of the most intense, perfectly paced moments in any platformer ever.

And the story‚Ä¶ oh man. Without spoiling anything, *Will of the Wisps* takes the simple fairy-tale vibe of the first game and gives it real emotional weight. The new characters (especially Ku and the supporting cast) are so endearing, and the ending left me quietly crying in the best way possible. It‚Äôs rare for a game to make me care this much about little glowing forest spirits.

Yes, there were a few minor launch bugs back in 2020, but on modern hardware (Xbox Series X, PC, or Switch now) it runs flawlessly. If you love Metroidvanias, platformers, beautiful art, or just games that respect your emotions, you owe it to yourself to play *Ori and the Will of the Wisps*. It‚Äôs not just one of the best Xbox exclusives ‚Äî it‚Äôs one of the best games of the entire generation.

Play it. Cry a little. Fall in love. Then immediately start it again on Hard mode like I did. ‚ú®

Ori and the Will of the Wisps eschews its predecessor's fondness for loneliness and some of its mechanical uniqueness for a focus on community and more conventional gameplay mechanics. While a great demonstration of game development learnings and offering up a more realized vision of the world, I cannot help but feel like this game takes on a number of elements from other Metroidvania games in a way that homogenizes the experience.

As someone who grew to love the isolatory experience of Ori and the Blind Forest, I initially had difficulty getting into Will of the Wisps and dropped the game for a week; I did care about NPCs, side-quests, a currency system, or a slightly deeper focus on combat! However, I wanted to learn why it made these changes. There are some additions made in Will of the Wisps to address critiques of the first game (namely, combat) while other changes were tonal in nature and heighten the climactic narrative scenes that became more of a focus.

Speed trials are a welcome addition to the game; they offer the player a substantial though not insurmountable challenge to demonstrate their learning of the game's myriad movement abilities. While combat was given more of a focus in Will of the Wisps, it did not get substantially more deep. Weapons and tools you can acquire are generally inferior to the movement abilities you have (with the exception of deeply powerful skill and accessory combination), and they ended up feeling more like accessories to sequence breaking than anything else in my playthrough. A shuriken felt ineffectual in combat yet vital in sniping doors or switches from beyond Ori's normal reach. This game's boss fights felt forgetful with the exception of two shortlived sequences that happen as a part of the fights. Combat trials were boring at best and a slog at worst.

But at its core, Ori and the Will of the Wisps remains a truly gorgeous game with a heavy focus on exploration. Both Ori games excel at distributing pick-ups in the Metroidvania genre, and Ori's signature Bash skill is an intuitive and powerful ability that makes the duology stand out. It is a series with two games that offer similar but distinct takes on what a Metroidvania game can be.

I am glad I gave Ori and the Will of the Wisps a second chance. It is a deeply beautiful experience that I can easily recommend to anyone of the genre, even if I still very much prefer the things its predecessor did.

[i]Ori and the Will of the Wisps[/i] is a masterwork. The game takes everything that made its predecessor great and enhances it, while adding new mechanics that greatly improve gameplay and expand the Ori universe.

In continuation from its predecessor, the game's visuals, lighting, and audio are as stunning as ever, and character movement and combat are fast and fluid. Worldbuilding extends upon what already exists in the Ori universe, with unique locations such as the coastal and colorful Luma Pools, the dark and scary spider's nest of Mouldwood, the cold and beautiful snowcapped Baur's Peak, and the sandy and desolate Windswept Wastes, all of which center around a magnificent Spirit Willow.

Ori's skill kit is greatly enhanced with a variety of weapons to keep enemies at bay and other utilities to aid mobility and survival, allowing for greater variety in the character's build. The environment itself presents new mechanics as well, from bubbles that can be redirected with a gust of wind to sand that can be burrowed through. There are also new monsters and environmental hazards to encounter, extending upon the Ori universe's biodiversity and danger.

One standout feature the game provides that its predecessor does not is boss fighting, pushing the Ori universe's biodiversity and danger even further. Additionally, boss fights add more variety to completing quests when chase scenes used to define quest resolution. All boss fights serve importance to the story in both heartwarming and heartbreaking ways.

And the soundtrack? Gareth Coker takes his music to the next level and surpasses even his amazing soundtrack for the game's predecessor. His music breathes life into every corner of the Ori universe, from environmental tracks, to chase scenes, to boss fights, to every uplifting and heartbreaking moment. His composition and arrangement of percussion, strings, woodwinds, brass, and vocals never cease to amaze and are quintessentially "Ori".

[i]Ori and the Will of the Wisps[/i] is truly a masterwork. Are you ready to go on a moving journey and embrace the light?

Replayed Ori and the Will of the Wisps. Highly benefitted from a second look because my first playthrough i wasnt in a great headspace and felt like i just had to get through the game and it felt highly derivative of games like Hollow Knight.

Second playthrough I really connected with it. Its way easier than some of the other metroidvanias, but that might be me being fresh off Silksong who is determined to mash your face into the ground until you choke and scream at you "are you crying yet?!" I wouldn't call it "easy" compared to games as a whole, its hard, but its not punishing. It doesnt use the bench/bonfire system its got a quicksave function so deaths set you back like a few feet allowing you to immediately retry challenges.

For a metroidvania its really lacking in the bossfight department. There's two really early ones that sort of set the stage and get me excited for a boss centric design.. but there's only a total of 5 true boss fights in the game. Ori and the Blind Forest was more set on chase sequences. The best part of both Ori's is the movement. Its a joy to move around in these games and Will of the Wisps builds on Blind Forest's frantic and fast paced movement. So its cool to see them lean into that with more chase sequences.

I do wish it was longer, I wish it had more stuff to do and more areas as the story and side quests fit nicely and neatly within each other. Again this might be a side effect of just played silksong, which was for me about 72 hours to 100% the game plus a few things that dont count as percentage that I still havent done. Ori WotW is an easy 16 hour 100% on Normal.

I would recommend playing both as the story is well presented and well told. You'll be lost at the beginning of the second one without playing the first, and I think the first one leans into its own strengths more, where the second kinda borrows mechanics from other metroidvanias, builds it on the fluid movement of the first, and that's where it really finds its stride.

All said, I highly recommend, 10/10.

My biggest critisicm would be that the difficulty settings are just dumb, (mainly looking at hard mode) all they do is just increase or decrease enemy and boss health and damage and the prices of stuff at shops which just feels like a pointless addition, if all a "hard mode" does in a game is make enemies take longer to kill and grinding money more tedious then what's even the point, (also the last phase of the final boss is horrible on hard mode just look it up for yourself)

7/10 it's a direct upgrade from the first game that I would wholeheartedly recommend playing.
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a pleasant romp of a Metroidvania. It's on the easy side, but the flow and speed of the platforming was a breath of fresh air coming from Silksong.

I just wanna play the game and they make it so difficult.

less about problem solving and more about perfect contoller timing and finding well obscured things. no real map markings, to breadcrumb where you need to return to for quest.

Good game, but it has a very low amount of enemy variety. About halfway through you will have seen every enemy the game throws at you. Bosses are few and far between with most being just mechanically boring chase sequences.

The graphics are pretty, but often hard to read, especially if there are a lot of neon colours on the screen. 

As far as movement unlocks go, there are a few great ones in there, but most are just basic stuff like double jump or dash, or even horrendously reused ones, like triple jump, dashing underwater or dashing in the sand.

All in all I'd give it a mixed review. The story is cute, but not deep enough to carry the game.
